title: Profile
text:
I am an interdisciplinary social and environmental psychologist whose work examines individual and collective responses to the climate and nature crisis. My research focuses on how identities, moral commitments, and social norms shape engagement with climate action, including participation in activism, responses to protest, and the way scientific communities and institutions position themselves in relation to the climate crisis. I am trained in anthropology (BA, MA), cognitive science (MSc), and social psychology (PhD), and have published high-quality research using a wide range of qualitative and quantitative methods, including surveys, interviews, focus groups, and ethnography.
My work spans three intersecting domains. First, I study science, communication, and society, with a particular focus on scientist climate advocacy, activism, and questions of credibility and public trust. Second, I examine collective climate action from two perspectives: 1) from the perspective of those engaged in collective action and 2) examining public responses to climate protest and civil disobedience. Third, I investigate institutional climate responses and leadership. My current work at Lancaster University, supported by the Wellcome Trust, explores the ethical and cultural dimensions of sustainability in UK higher education, including how universities conceptualise their responsibilities in addressing the climate crisis.
I have held senior research roles at both the University of Bristol, where I worked across the Schools of Psychology and Policy Studies researching public attitudes to disruptive climate protest, and at Lancaster University, where I am based in the Social Processes Group within the Department of Psychology conducting research on scientist advocacy and activism, research culture, and universities’ climate responses. These positions have allowed me to combine interdisciplinary research, applied policy engagement, and collaborative projects with academic and non-academic partners.

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching Associate, Jan – May 2024
Designed and delivered lectures and labs for undergraduate qualitative methods, and managed teaching assistants during both teaching and marking.
Teaching Assistant, Oct 2019 – Oct 2023
Delivered undergraduate teaching across Psychology modules including Cognitive Psychology, Developmental Psychology, Neuropsychology, Personality & Individual Differences, Research Methods, Statistics, R Programming, and Open Science Practices. Led RStudio support sessions for student projects. Over 600+ hours total teaching time.
Supervision
Supervised three undergraduate research projects (2022–23).
Guest Lectures,
Delivered guest lectures for postgraduate modules in psychology and sustainability, including SGA420 Navigating Sustainability and Global Environmental Futures: “Climate Futures Between Collapse and Transformation: Scientists’ Discourse and the Politics of Possibility” in 2025 and Masters in Social Psychology PSYCH601 “The Psychology of Scientist Activism

Awards & Recognition

Associate Fellowship of the UK Higher Education Authority (2021) for completion of the Associate Teacher Programme.
